content.description:
Ton of Brix is an awesome moderate on clean, well-featured rock that resembles a "mini-Air Wolf" from the right angle. Climb the right-hand arete up to the roof, make a committing reach to a jug, and find an easy topout around the roof's left side.

The cider for which this route is named can be found at the cidery in town and is highly recommended for post climbing refreshment!
content.location: This will be the first boulder you come to after scrambling down through the cliff band and following the path for a little ways. It has a slightly built up and evened out landing.

content.description: Snaggletooth is a lowball! Start matched on a juggy undercling, and make a couple powerful moves up sloping edges to the top.
content.location:
Walk around

Ocaso

and the main, boxcar-shaped boulder, and find the rounded Snaggletooth Boulder just downhill. Snaggletooth sits on the north face of the boulder and is the only side that's particularly featured.

content.description:
This is an area classic! Ocaso climbs out of a pit via a tricky compression sequence before gaining a juggy arete and riding it to the heavens. The grade is somewhat ambiguous, but it's kinda reachy while also being kinda scrunchy. There's certainly a few different ways to climb it, but start low, bear-hugging with your left hand on the arete and your right hand on an undercling. It's both balancy and powerful.

Climbing just the arete from a stand start makes for a fun V0 in itself. The 'PG-13' just acknowledges the potential for a weird fall at any point, due to the nature of the pit and the backscratcher boulder behind you. Falling from any point on the arete is ill-advised, but if you made it that far, you won't.
content.protection: 1-2 pads. A spotter or additional pile of foam does little to mitigate the awkward fall potential.
content.location:
Left of "

Ton of Brix

" and the TR flake on the main boulder, look for a tall, clean, orange face rising out of a pit. It is north-facing.

content.description:
On the cliff band across from

Ton of Brix

and

Ocaso

, traverse the shelf on a mix of jugs and slopers. It's a nice warm-up, but as the name implies, things could get a little poopy.

A higher traverse, as well as a variety of eliminates and "hit the jug and drop" type problems, can also be found in and around this route.
content.location: On the main cliff-band, west facing, climber's left of all the TR routes. Look for the obvious shelf/rail directly across from the main boulder.
